{{Infobox military person |name = Giorgakis Olympios |native_name = {{lang-el|Γιωργάκης Ολύμπιος}}
{{lang-ro|Iordache Olimpiotul}} |birth_date = 1772 |death_date = {{death year and age|1821|1772}} |birth_place = [[Livadi]], [[Larissa]], [[Ottoman Empire]] |death_place = [[Neamţ County|Neamţ]], [[Moldavia]] |image = Georgakis Olympios Greek Fighter.JPG |image_size = 180 |nickname = |birth_name = |allegiance = {{plainlist| *{{flagicon image|Greek Revolution flag.svg}} [[First Hellenic Republic|Greek revolutionaries]] *{{flagicon image|FLAG_Topola.gif}} [[Serbian revolution]]aries }} |serviceyears = |rank = |commands = |battles = {{plainlist| *[[First Serbian Uprising]] (1804-1806) *[[Greek War of Independence]] (1817-1821) }} |awards = }} '''Giorgakis Olympios''' ({{lang-el|Γιωργάκης Ολύμπιος}}; {{lang-ro|Iordache Olimpiotul}}; 1772–1821) was a [[Greeks|Greek]] ''[[Armatoloi|armatolos]]'' and military commander during the [[Greek War of Independence]] against the [[Ottoman Empire]]. Noted for his activities with the [[Filiki Eteria]] in the [[Danubian Principalities]], he is considered to be a leading figure of the Greek Revolution. ==Biography== ===Early activities=== Olympios was of [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] origin.{{cite book|author=Giannēs Koliopoulos|title=Λεηλασία Φρονημάτων|quote=... of a separate Vlach armed band, named after Georgakis Olympios, the Vlach hero of the Greek War of Independence.|page=85}} He was born in the village of [[Livadi]], near [[Larissa]], on [[Mount Olympus]], in [[Ottoman Greece|Ottoman-ruled Greece]]. After joining the ''Armatolikia'' in the Olympus area around the age of 20, Olympios became a prominent member of the local society by protecting villages from the [[Ali Pasha of Ioannina|Ali Pasha]]'s raids, when the powerful Pasha started expanding his authority out of [[Epirus]]. In 1798, however, he was forced to abandon his birthplace, due to Ali Pasha's hostility towards him, and fled to [[Serbia]], where he collaborated for some time with [[Karađorđe Petrović]] during the [[First Serbian Uprising]] (he is known in Serbia as Kapetan Jorgać, ''Captain Giorgakis''). Olympios became a supporter of the ideas diffused by [[Rigas Feraios]] for a common [[Balkans|Balkan]] revolution against the Ottoman rule, and moved to [[Wallachia]]. There, with the help of [[Constantine Ypsilantis]], he composed a military force of [[Greeks]] to fight alongside the [[Russian Empire]] in the [[Russo-Turkish War (1806–1812)|Russo-Turkish War of 1806]]. After the [[Battle of Ostrova]], he was named a ''[[Polkovnik]]'' in the [[Military history of Imperial Russia|Russian Army]]. [[List of Russian rulers|Emperor]] [[Alexander I of Russia|Alexander I]] included him in the Russian military escort during the [[Congress of Vienna]], where Olympios met with [[Alexander Ypsilantis]], a [[Filiki Eteria]] leader. ===Greek War of Independence=== Olympios entered Filiki Eteria in 1817, taking the high rank of ''Shepherd''. He initiated many others in the Eteria, and established contacts with the Wallachian [[Vladimirescu's Pandurs|Pandur]] [[Tudor Vladimirescu]], who led the parallel [[Wallachian uprising of 1821|uprising of 1821]]. Olympios married [[Čučuk Stana]], the widow of [[Veljko Petrović|Hajduk Veljko]], who had arrived from Serbia to participate in the Greek War of Independence as a fighter, alongside his own men. They had three children: sons Milanos and Alexandros and daughter Euphrosyne.{{Not in citation given||reason=Names of offspring not mentioned in source.|date=February 2018}} At the beginning of the [[Greek War of Independence]], when the Eteria began its expedition in [[Moldavia]] and Wallachia, Olympios was appointed leader of the Greek forces in [[Bucharest]] by Alexander Ypsilantis, at first cooperating with [[Tudor Vladimirescu]], who led the parallel [[Wallachian uprising (1821)|Wallachian uprising]]. However, when Vladimirescu distanced himself from the Fililiki Eteria, Olympios was responsible for his arrest on 1 June in [[Bălilești|Goleşti]] - following which Vladimirescu was summarily put to death . He took part in the [[Battle of Sculeni]] on 29 June 1821, when Ottoman forces chased him (along with [[Yiannis Pharmakis]] and a small force of 400 Greeks) to the [[Secu Monastery]] in the [[Neamț County]], where the Greeks made their last stand. Olympios died during the Ottoman attack on the monastery. His widow and children fled to [[Khotyn]], then part of the [[Bessarabia Governorate]] of the [[Russian Empire]], where other people of the [[Serbian revolution|Serbian]]- and Greek War, had taken refuge. After the liberation of [[Greece]], Stana and her children moved to [[Athens]].[Δημήτρης Φωτιάδης,Επανάσταση του 21 , τ.Α,σ.445] ==See also== *[[Hadži-Prodan Gligorijević]], fellow Serbian revolutionary that participated in the same wars *[[Vasos Mavrovouniotis]], fellow Montenegrin Serb revolutionary that participated in the Greek War ==References== {{reflist}} *Paroulakis, Peter H. ''The Greeks: Their Struggle For Independence''. Hellenic International Press, 1984. {{ISBN|0-9590894-1-1}}. *Stratiki, Poti. ''To Athanato 1821''. Stratikis Bros, 1990. {{ISBN|960-7261-50-X}}. ==External links== *[http://www.elassona.com.gr/m_elassona/iprosopa/giorgakisolympios.php Biography of Giorgakis Olympios] {{Greek War of Independence|state=collapsed}} {{Serbian revolutionaries}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Olympios, Giorgakis}} [[Category:1772 births]] [[Category:1821 deaths]] [[Category:People from Larissa (regional unit)]] [[Category:1820s in Romania]] [[Category:Members of the Filiki Eteria]] [[Category:People of the Greek War of Independence]] [[Category:People of the First Serbian Uprising]] [[Category:Russian military personnel]] [[Category:History of Wallachia (1821–59)]] [[Category:Greek people of Aromanian descent]] [[Category:Greek military personnel killed in action]]

[[University of Grenoble]]
[[Pantheon-Sorbonne University]] |religion = [[Islam]] |website = [http://hazembeblawi.com/ Official website] }} '''Hazem Abdel Aziz El Beblawi''' (also spelled ''el Beblawy''; {{lang-ar|حازم عبد العزيز الببلاوى}}  {{IPA-arz|ˈħæːzem ʕæbdel.ʕæˈziːz elbebˈlæːwi|pron}}; born 17 October 1936) is an Egyptian economist and politician who was interim [[Prime Minister of Egypt]] from 2013 until 1 March 2014. Previously he served as Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance in 2011. After the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|July 2013 ouster]] of President [[Mohammed Morsi]] and his government, Beblawi was named interim Prime Minister.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/egypt-spokesman-economist-hazem-el-biblawi-named-prime-minister-elbaradei-vice-president/2013/07/09/e2f532e2-e8a4-11e2-818e-aa29e855f3ab_story.html|title=Egypt spokesman: Economist Hazem el-Biblawi named prime minister; ElBaradei vice president|newspaper=Washington Post|agency=Associated Press|date=9 July 2013}} On 24 February 2014, Beblawi announced his resignation. ==Early life and education== Beblawi was born in [[Cairo, Egypt]] on 17 October 1936.{{cite web|title=Dr. Hazem Beblawi|url=http://www.erf.org.eg/CMS/uploads/pdf/1194810121_Hazem_El_Beblawi_CV_07.pdf|publisher=ERF|accessdate=17 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928001049/http://www.erf.org.eg/CMS/uploads/pdf/1194810121_Hazem_El_Beblawi_CV_07.pdf|archivedate=28 September 2013|df=dmy-all}} He studied law at [[Cairo University]] and graduated in 1957.{{cite web|title=Beblawi's CV|url=http://www.mof.gov.eg/MOFGallerySource/English/Dr.Hazem-cv.pdf|publisher=Ministry of Finance|accessdate=3 March 2013}}{{cite news|author=Basil Dabh|title=Hazem Al Beblawi appointed Prime Minister|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/07/09/hazem-al-beblawi-appointed-prime-minister/|accessdate=15 July 2013|newspaper=Daily News Egypt|date=9 July 2013}} He obtained a postgraduate degree in economics from the [[University of Grenoble]] in 1961. He also holds a PhD in economics, which he received from [[Pantheon-Sorbonne University|the University of Paris]] 1 Pantheon-Sorbonne in 1964. ==Career== Beblawi began his career as a lecturer at the [[University of Alexandria]] in 1965 and taught economy-related courses at several universities, including the [[University of Southern California]], until 1980.{{cite news|last=Bradley|first=Matt|title=Egypt Premier Known as Free-Market Champion|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324507404578595693142086644|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=9 July 2013|location=Cairo}} He became a manager at the [[Industrial Bank of Kuwait]] in 1980, serving there until 1983. From 1983 to 1995, he was chairman and chief executive of the Export Development Bank in Egypt. Then he worked at the [[Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia|United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia]] (ESCWA) as executive secretary from 1995 to 2000. Next, he served as an advisor to the [[Arab Monetary Fund]] in [[Abu Dhabi]] from 2001 to 2011.{{cite web|title=Senior Associate|url=http://www.erf.org.eg/cms.php?id=erf_affiliates_senior_associates_details&affiliates_id=283|work=Economic Research Forum|accessdate=3 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212164423/http://www.erf.org.eg/cms.php?id=erf_affiliates_senior_associates_details&affiliates_id=283|archivedate=12 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}[http://www.sis.gov.eg/newVR/figure2011/english/enmoaser/htm/beblawi.htm Hazem Al Beblawi] ''SIS''. 2011. Retrieved 10 December 2013. After the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|January–February 2011 Egyptian revolution]], Beblawi became a founding member of the [[Egyptian Social Democratic Party]].{{cite news|title=Egypt's finance minister resigns, Beblawi officially appointed|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/3/12/16611/Business/Economy/Egypts-finance-minister-resigns,-Beblawi-officiall.aspx|accessdate=3 March 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=17 July 2011}}{{cite news|title=New Egyptian finance minister appointed|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/3b02425a-b07a-11e0-a5a7-00144feab49a.html#axzz2es2qf23G|accessdate=14 September 2013|newspaper=Financial Times|date=17 July 2011|author=Issandr El Amrani|location=Cairo}} He was appointed to the government as Deputy Prime Minister for Economic Affairs, as well as Minister of Finance, in a [[cabinet reshuffle]] on 17 July 2011.{{cite news|title=Egypt's new Finance Minister Hazem el Beblawi|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/17/us-egypt-minister-factbox-idUSTRE76G18Z20110717|accessdate=3 March 2013|work=Reuters|date=17 July 2011|location=Cairo}}{{cite news|title=Egypt's new cabinet unveils|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-07/18/c_13991026.htm|accessdate=3 March 2013|work=Xinhua|date=18 July 2011|author=Li Laifang|author2=Marwa Yehia|location=Cairo|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002044153/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-07/18/c_13991026.htm|archivedate=2 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} He succeeded [[Samir Radwan]], who had served as finance minister since January 2011.{{cite news|title=Egypt's new cabinet to be sworn in|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/07/2011717232716512838.html|accessdate=3 March 2013|work=Al Jazeera|date=18 July 2011}} [[Sharaf Cabinet|The cabinet]] was headed by Prime Minister [[Essam Sharaf]].{{cite news|last1=Kirkpatrick|first1=David D.|title=A Top Egyptian Minister Quits in Protest Over Killings|work=The New York Times|page=10|date=12 October 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/12/world/middleeast/egypts-finance-minister-resigns.html}}{{cite news|title=A list of Egypt's Cabinet reshuffle|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContentPrint/1/0/16684/Egypt/0/A-list-of-Egypts-Cabinet-reshuffle-.aspx|accessdate=3 March 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=18 July 2011}}{{cite news|title=Egyptian prime minister shuffles Cabinet|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jul/18/world/la-fg-egypt-cabinet-20110718|accessdate=5 March 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=18 July 2011|author=Amro Hassan|author2=Jeffrey Fleishman|location=Cairo}} After nearly four months in office, Beblawi resigned from office in October 2011 when [[Coptic Christians]] were killed by security forces. However, his resignation was not accepted by the ruling military council.{{cite news|title=Egypt to keep planning minister, appoint Momtaz Said as finance head: reports|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/3/12/28317/Business/Economy/Egypt-to-keep-planning-minister,-appoint-Momtaz-Sa.aspx|accessdate=3 March 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=2 December 2011|agency=Reuters}}{{cite news|title=Egypt’s deputy PM back at work after resignation rejected|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2011/10/12/egypt-finance-minister-back-at-work-after-resignation-rejected/|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=Daily News Egypt|date=12 October 2011}} Beblawi's tenure lasted until December 2011, when he was replaced by [[Momtaz El-Saeed|Momtaz Saeed]] as finance minister; Saeed had served as Beblawi's deputy at the Ministry of Finance.{{cite news|last=Gamal|first=Wael|title='No' to borrowing on the terms of the IMF, Ganzouri and their successors|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContentP/4/51316/Opinion/No-to-borrowing-on-the-terms-of-the-IMF,-Ganzouri-.aspx|accessdate=3 March 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=26 August 2012}} Beblawi was one of the nominees for prime minister after the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]], together with [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] and [[Farouk El Okdah]].{{cite news|last=Tarek|first=Sherif|title=Egypt's next government remains anyone's guess|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/46766/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-next-government-remains-anyones-guess.aspx|accessdate=3 March 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=3 July 2012}} Following the removal of President [[Mohammad Morsi]] from office by the Egyptian military on 3 July 2013, Beblawi was appointed as interim Prime Minister on 9 July.{{cite news|last=Bacon|first=John|title=Egypt names new prime minister|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/07/09/egypt-prime-minister-el-biblawi/2501703/|accessdate=9 July 2013|work=USA Today|date=9 July 2013}} He subsequently suspended his membership in the Egyptian Social Democratic Party.{{cite news|title=El Beblawi continues to meet ministerial candidates|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/07/15/el-beblawi-continues-to-meet-ministerial-candidates/|accessdate=16 July 2013|newspaper=Daily News Egypt|date=15 July 2013|author=Joel Gulhane|author2=Charlie Miller}} [[Beblawi Cabinet|His cabinet]] was sworn in on 16 July 2013.{{cite news|title=Egypt's interim president is swearing in first government|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/76619/Egypt/Politics-/BREAKING-Egypts-interim-president-is-swearing-in-f.aspx|accessdate=16 July 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=16 July 2013}} On 24 February 2014, Prime Minister Beblawi announced the resignation of his cabinet in a press conference.{{cite news|author1=Kareem Fahim|author2=Mayy El Sheikh|title=Government and Premier of Egypt Quit in Abrupt Move|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/25/world/middleeast/egypts-prime-minister-resigns.html?_r=0|accessdate=8 September 2014|work=The New Tork Times|date=25 February 2014|location=Cairo}} ===Activities and views=== Beblawi defended the military's crackdown on Morsi supporters after the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état as necessary and restrained in August 2013.{{cite news|title=Egyptian PM Hazem Al Beblawi defends action against protesters|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/egyptian-pm-hazem-albeblawi-defends-action-against-protesters/414403-2.html|accessdate=15 August 2013|work=IBN Live|date=15 August 2013}} He proposed the legal dissolution of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] on 17 August.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/17/us-egypt-protests-brotherhood-status-idUSBRE97G03X20130817 Egyptian premier proposes dissolution of Muslim Brotherhood] ''Reuters'', 17 August 2013 ===Works=== Beblawi is the author of several books mostly about banking, finance, international trade and development.{{cite news|title=Hazem Beblawi: Hard on Mubarak's regime, soft on businessmen|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/3/12/16741/Business/Economy/Hazem-Beblawi-Hard-on-Mubaraks-regime,-soft-on-bus.aspx|accessdate=3 March 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=18 July 2011|author=Marwa Hussein|author2=Salma El Wardani}} He also writes articles in a column for ''[[Al-Ahram|Al Ahram]]''. His books include: *{{Cite book|last=Beblawi|first=Hazem|title=Arba Shohour Fi Qafas Al Hokouma (Four Months in the Government’s Cage')|publisher=Shrouk Publishing House|location= Cairo|date=2012}}{{cite news|title=Hazem El Beblawi puts his finger on the core problems of Egypt's economy|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/18/62/76467/Books/Review/From-the-Ahram-archives-Hazem-ElBeblawi-puts-his-f.aspx|accessdate=16 July 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=4 February 2012}} *{{Cite book|last=Beblawi|first=Hazem|author2=Giacomo Luciani|year=1987|title=The Rentier State|publisher=Croom Helm|location=London|isbn=978-0709941446}} * Beblawi, Hazem. (1984). ''The Arab Gulf Economy in a Turbulent Age''. London: Croom Helm. ===Awards=== * [[File:Legion Honneur Chevalier ribbon.svg|50px]] [[Chevalier de la Légion d'honneur]] from [[France]] in 1992. *[[File:BEL Order of Leopold II - Commander BAR.png|50px]] Commander, [[Order of Leopold II|the order of Leopold II]] from [[Belgium]] in 1992. * [[File:Order of the Cedar - Grand Officer (Lebanon) Ribbon.png|50px]] Grand Officier, [[National Order of the Cedar]] from [[Lebanon]] in 2000. ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|rows=2|before=[[Samir Radwan]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Ministry of Finance (Egypt)|Minister of Finance]]|years=2011}} {{s-aft|rows=2|after=[[Momtaz El-Saeed]]}} |- {{s-ttl|title=Deputy Prime Minister of Egypt|years=2011}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Hesham Qandil]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Prime Minister of Egypt]]

[[File:Hiroshi Onishi.jpg|thumb|Hiroshi Ōnishi (1993)]]
{{nihongo|'''Hiroshi Ōnishi'''|大西 博}} (June 18, 1961 – March 31, 2011) was a Japanese painter and university professor.
==Life and work== === Youth and Early Work === Born on June 18, 1961, on [[Shikoku Island]], in [[Tokushima Prefecture]], he grew up in [[Osaka]] from the age of three. Two significant incidents during his childhood awakened his interest in Western culture: the 1970 [[Expo '70|World's fair in Osaka]], and the instructions in Western painting by the artist Kakuichi Shikawa. When he was 12, his family moved to [[Tokyo]], where he passed the entrance examinations for the Tokyo University of the Arts ([[Tokyo Geijutsu Daigaku|Tōkyō Geijutsu Daigaku]]) in 1983. In 1989 he completed his studies with a Masters in Art Theory, specializing in Oil Painting, Technique and Materials. His thesis work “La Truite” (“The Trout”, 1987) was purchased by the Japanese Ministry of Culture.<ref>[http://db.am.geidai.ac.jp/object.cgi?id=22780 La Truite (Website, Tokyo University of the Arts)]</ref> His second work, “The Salmon”, 1989 by the [[Daiwa Bank]]. During this phase, he oriented his work strongly toward the European [[Renaissance]], in which his human forms are evocative of [[Albrecht Dürer]] or [[Matthias Grünewald]], in combination with his conceptions of fish and water. After his academic studies he worked for one year as a research assistant in the Department of Oil Painting, Technique and Materials.
=== Murals === In subsequent years he created more surreal and expressive oil paintings. Simultaneously, from 1983 to 1992, he worked as a [[mural]]ist for the department store Shibuya PARCO in Tokyo. Later in his writings, he called this job Kaisha ni okeru katsudō (in English, “the establishment-concerned workings”). On surfaces of 4.5 x 13m, respectively, 4.5 x 9m, he painted advertisements for various products on the exterior walls of the department store. In the beginning he painted solo, later he engaged additional artists for these assignments.
=== Academic Studies in Germany === From 1992 to 1997, Hiroshi Onishi studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in [[Nuremberg]], Germany under Günter Dollhopf. In 1996 he was designated a Master Student. His experimentation with paper, acrylic, India ink, fabric and pigments became a quest for his Japanese roots.
=== Return to Japan and Main Work === [[File:色景 (Landschaft).jpg|thumb|„View of Remembrance I“ (2009). 3,88 x 1,94 m, lapislazuli canvas]] [[File:Schiebetüren für Nanzen-ji.jpeg|thumb|Fusuma-e for Nanzen-ji, Omotesando Gallery Exhibition, Tokyo, 2011]] In February 1998 he returned to Japan, initially to work as an Assistant Professor, later as a Professor, at his [[alma mater]], Tokyo University of the Arts. In 2003, on assignment from the University, he undertook two trips to Afghanistan where he discovered the mineral [[lapis lazuli]] as a raw material for his work and rediscovered it as a pigment for traditional painting. This [[ultramarine]] pigment, created through an extremely complex process, he initially used for his painting and later for the creation of tea ceremony implements. Together with the Japanese company Holbein Ltd., he developed a premium quality lapis lazuli watercolor.
As Professor in the Department of Oil Painting, Technique and Material at the Tōkyō Geijutsu Daigaku he taught the traditional production of the lapis lazuli pigment in the tradition of [[Cennino Cennini]] from 1300 A.D.
Sensational exhibitions of this painting technique led to his most important and honored assignment: on the plot of a famous Zen Temple in Kyoto, the [[Nanzen-ji]], he was to paint a hall in the Tenjuan Temple with his lapis lazuli technique. This work comprised 73 [[Fusuma]]-e (paintings on sliding doors). He was able to complete 12 Fusuma-e.
On March 31, 2011, he died in a boating accident on [[Lake Biwa]], aged 49.
=== A Retrospective of his Work === From March 20 to April 8, 2012 the first show of his collective works took place posthumously on the campus of the Tōkyō Geijutsu Daigaku titled, “ONISHI HIROSHI Retrospective – View of Remembrance 大西博 回顧展 幻景“.<ref>[http://www.geidai.ac.jp/museum/exhibit/2012/oonishi/oonishi_en.htm ONISHI HIROSHI Retrospective – View of Remembrance (Website, Tokyo University of The Arts)]</ref> Next to his many early works, oil paintings created using his lapis lazuli technique were also shown. In addition, the collection of tea ceremony utensils was presented for the first time. It consists of 30 ceremonial teacups fired with lapis lazuli pigment. Also included were accessories in bamboo and wood, which were lacquered with lapis lazuli pigment.
For Hiroshi Onishi the link between Eastern and Western painting was a central theme. A part of his work is now in Germany with his widow, Martina Wagner-Onishi.<ref>[http://ruriko.de/ RURIKO - Intercultural meeting place between Germany and Japan]</ref>
== Exhibitions == ===Solo exhibitions=== * 1989 Ginza Surugadai Gallery, Tokyo * 1990 Ginza JBC Gallery, Tokyo * 1994 Gold/Pfeil, [[Nuremberg]] * 1998 Gallery Fukuyama, Tokyo * 1999 Fuji Gallery, Osaka * 2000 Yokohama Galeria Bellini Hill Gallery, [[Kanagawa-ku, Yokohama|Kanagawa]] * 2002 Gallery Mori, Tokyo * 2005 Gallery OPEN DOOR, Tokyo * 2011 Gallery Omotesando, Tokyo * 2012 The Chinretsukan Gallery, Tokyo University of the Arts, Tokyo
=== Group Exhibitions (Selection) === * 1987 Graduation Exhibition ([[Bachelor of Fine Arts|BFA]]) * 1989 Graduation Exhibition ([[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]]) * 1993 Große Kunst Ausstellung, [[Haus der Kunst]], [[Munich]] * 1994 Siebold in Japan, Siebold-Stiftung, [[Würzburg]] * 1996 Ausstellung der Dollhopf-Klasse, [[Schwabach]] * 1997 From The Collection of The University Art Museum, Tokyo, Osaka, [[Kyoto]], [[Nagoya]] * 1999 At Center of Corridor, Yokohama Galeria Bellini Hill Gallery, Kanagawa; STOP OVER, Nuremberg Academy of Art, Nuremberg * 2002 NEWS’, The University Art Museum, Tokyo * 2003 Art Workshop School Exhibition, [[Myōkō, Niigata|Myōkō]], Akakura-Onsen, [[Niigata Prefecture]] * 2004 Fuji Gallery and Teo Art Gallery; Japan-South Korea Exchange Exhibition, [[Busan]], [[South Korea]] * 2005 Reflex – Development and Construction of Contemporary Methods of Gold Leaf and Tempera – The University Art Museum, Tokyo; Coexistence in the Same Mind, Korean Craft Museum, [[Cheongju]] * 2006 Three Histories, PICI Gallery, [[Seoul]], South-Korea; The Legend of Minakami, Minakami Mizu Kiko Kan, [[Gunma Prefecture]]; Japan-South Korea Exchange Exhibition, Changwon Gallery, [[Changwon]], South-Korea * 2007 Artists’ Oil Color, The University Art Museum, Tokyo * 2009 Layer/inner-sight, Galerie Omotesando, Tokyo; Asian Contemporary Art Drawings Exhibition, The University Art Museum, Tokyo * 2010 ITSU-Japanese Painting Beyond Tradition, Hillside Forum, Tokyo; SOFA, Park Avenue Armory, [[New York City]] * 2011 Galerie Omotesando, Tokyo; „SIX Esprits – from West“, Gallery EM, [[Nagasaki]]; „Tradition Present break up“ painting exhibition, The University Art Museum, Tokyo; „Homage to Akihiko Takami“, Galerie Omotesando, Tokyo * 2013 Ceramic Class of Prof. Makoto Toyofuku, The University Art Museum, Tokyo * 2014 „Seeing objects, painting objects“ Oil Painting, Department of Material and Techniques and other Artists, The University Art Museum, Tokyo
=== Tea Ceremonies === [[File:Teezeremonie in Myoko.jpg|thumb|Tea Ceremony in Myōkō]] On the occasion of the 120th Anniversary of the Tokyo University of the Arts, a four-day event „Geidai Chakai“ (tea convention of the Geidai) took place in October 2007. For this event, Hiroshi Onishi created multiple implements for [[tea ceremonies]], among them the first teacup fired with a glaze of lapislazuli pigment. Additional public tea ceremonies followed.
* 2007 Tea Ceremony „Geidai Chakai“, The University Art Museum, Tokyo * 2008–2010 Tea Ceremonies in Akakura-Onsen, [[Myōkō, Niigata|Myōkō]], [[Niigata Prefecture]] * 2010 Tea Ceremony Matsuen-kai, [[Nezu Museum]], Tokyo
== Literature == * GEIDAI CHAKAI (eds.: Geidai Chakai Executive Committee and Faculty of Fine Arts, Tokyo University of the Arts), 2008 * Ōnishi Hiroshi Retrospective – View of Remembrance. Exhibition Catalogue, Tokyo University of the Arts, 2012 * RURIKO Legende (eds.: Faculty of Fine Arts, University of the Arts), 2012

'''Ifa Muaza''' (or '''Isa Muaza'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ncadc.org.uk/right-to-remain/isa-muaza/|title=Isa Muazu: Act now – demand Home Office lifts "death sentence"|date=20 November 2013|accessdate=22 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opendemocracy.net/5050/eiri-ohtani/isa-muazu-hunger-striker-and-us-monster|title=Isa Muazu, the hunger striker and us, the monster|date=22 November 2013|accessdate=22 November 2013}}</ref>) is a [[Nigeria|Nigerian]] man who went on [[hunger strike]] while unsuccessfully attempting to claim [[asylum seeker|asylum]] in the [[United Kingdom]] in 2013.
Ifa Muaza claimed to have left his home in Nigeria because members of the [[proscribed]] [[Islamist]] group [[Boko Haram]] threatened to kill him if he did not join them. After being held in custody at the [[Harmondsworth Immigration Removal Centre]] in the [[United Kingdom]],<ref name="guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/19/asylum-seeker-hunger-strike-stay-custody-death-nigeria-muaza|title=Dying asylum seeker on hunger strike must stay in custody, says high court|date=19 November 2013|accessdate=21 November 2013|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''}}</ref> he started a [[hunger strike]] on 26 August 2013.<ref name="guardian" /> By mid-November he was expected to die if not released.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/16/end-of-life-plan-hunger-striker|title=Home Office issues 'end of life plan' to hunger-striking asylum seeker|date=16 November 2013|accessdate=21 November 2013|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''}}</ref> An attempt was made to deport him on Friday 30 November,<ref>{{cite web|author=Alan Travis |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/29/failed-asylum-seeker-deported-hunger-strike-ifa-muaza|title=Failed asylum seeker deported from UK after 100-day hunger strike| UK news |publisher=The Guardian |date=30 November 2013 |accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref> which failed when the plane was refused access to Nigerian airspace. The attempt is estimated to have cost the Home Office between £95,000 and £110,000.<ref>{{cite web|last=McVeigh|first=Tracy|title=Theresa May under fire for bid to fly out hunger striker Ifa Muaza|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/30/theresa-may-hunger-striker-ifa-muaza-asylum-uk|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref> He was eventually removed from the UK on 17 December 2013.

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox Minister | name = Jacek Cichocki | image = Jacek Cichocki.jpg | imagesize = 150px | caption = | office = [[Chancellery of the Prime Minister of Poland|Chief of the Chancellery]] | primeminister = [[Donald Tusk]]
[[Ewa Kopacz]] | predecessor = [[Tomasz Arabski]] | successor = [[Beata Kempa]] | term_start = 25 February 2013 | term_end = 16 November 2015 | office1 = [[Ministry of Interior (Poland)|Minister of Interior]] | primeminister1= [[Donald Tusk]] | predecessor1 = [[Jerzy Miller (politician)|Jerzy Miller]] | successor1 = [[Bartłomiej Sienkiewicz]] | term_start1 = 18 November 2011 | term_end1 = 25 February 2013 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|12|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Warsaw]], Poland | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | party = Independent | residence = | alma_mater = [[Warsaw University]] | spouse = | nationality = [[Polish people|Polish]] | religion= | children = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Jacek Cichocki''' (born 17 December 1971) is an independent Polish politician and a former member of the [[Cabinet of Poland|Polish Council of Ministers]]. Cichocki served as the [[Ministry of the Interior (Poland)|minister of interior]] in the [[Second Cabinet of Donald Tusk|second cabinet]] of [[Prime Minister of Poland|Prime Minister]] [[Donald Tusk]] and later as [[Chancellery of the Prime Minister of Poland|chief of the Chancellery]] for Tusk and his successor [[Ewa Kopacz]] ==Early life and education== Cichocki was born in [[Warsaw]] on 17 December 1971.{{cite journal|last=Matraszek|first=Marek|title=Composition of the new government after the 2011 parliamentary elections in the Republic of Poland|journal=CEC|date=November 2011|url=http://contact.bpcc.org.pl/issue04/pdf/Polish_Government2011.pdf|accessdate=28 March 2013}} He received a bachelor's degree in philosophy and sociology from the [[University of Warsaw]]. ==Career== Cichocki began his career as an expert on armed conflict and ethnic tensions within the former [[Soviet Union]] for the [[Centre for Eastern Studies]] in 1992, working for the centre until 2008. Additionally, Cichocki also was employed as a programme assistant at the [[Stefan Batory Foundation]] for its East-Central Europe Forum, where he worked from 1995 to 1997. He became deputy director of the Centre for Eastern Studies in 2001. From 2004 to 2007, he served as the head of the centre.{{cite news|title=History of OSW|url=http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/history-osw|accessdate=28 March 2013|work=The Centre for Eastern Studies}} Following this term, Cichocki joined the government of Prime Minister [[Donald Tusk]], working as a secretary of state for security services in the Chancellery from 2007 to November 2011.{{cite news|title=Bugging Scandal Sparks Big Brother Fears|url=http://www.europeansocialsurvey.org/index.php/index.php?view=details&id=5751%3Abugging-scandal-sparks-big-brother-fears&option=com_eventlist&Itemid=326|accessdate=28 March 2013|work=Warsaw Voice|year=2009}} Following a cabinet reshuffle by Prime Minister Tusk, Cichocki was appointed interior minister in Tusk's [[Second Cabinet of Donald Tusk|second cabinet]] on 18 November 2011, where Cichocki presided over the nation's law enforcement services.{{cite web|title=President appointed the new government|url=http://www.president.pl/en/news/news/art,236,president-appointed-the-new-government.html|publisher=President of Poland|accessdate=18 November 2011}} Cichocki replaced [[Jerzy Miller (politician)|Jerzy Miller]] in the post. During his tenure, Cichocki presided over security operations during the [[UEFA Euro 2012|UEFA Euro 2012 football championship]], defending the event's security preparations and the [[Policja]]'s response to the 12 June 2012 violent clashes between Polish and Russian fans in [[Warsaw]] coinciding with a match between both teams.{{cite news|title=Euro 2012: Poland minister calls for severe sanctions on hooligans|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/jun/13/euro-2012-poland-russia-hooligans|accessdate=5 February 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=13 June 2012}} Following the riot, Cichocki demanded prosecutors to aggressively pursue legal actions against detained Polish hooligans to "fully feel the consequences of their antics," while ordering arrested Russian fans to be deported and excluded from entering the [[Schengen Area]] for five years. Cichocki concluded after the championship's completion that far fewer people were arrested during the events than had been expected.{{cite web|title=‘Much less arrests than expected’ during Euro 2012|url=http://www.thenews.pl/1/203/Artykul/104541,%E2%80%98Much-less-arrests-than-expected%E2%80%99-during-Euro-2012-says-Interior-Minister|work=Polskie Radio|accessdate=2 July 2012}} Cichocki's tenure at the interior ministry lasted until 25 February 2013, when he was replaced by [[Bartłomiej Sienkiewicz]]. Cichocki was then subsequently reshuffled in the cabinet to become chief of the chancellery, replacing Tomasz Arabski in the post.{{cite web|title=Prime Minister announces 'small but interesting' cabinet reshuffle|url=http://www.thenews.pl/1/9/Artykul/127815,Prime-Minister-announces-small-but-interesting-cabinet-reshuffle|work=Polskie Radio|accessdate=20 February 2013}} Cichocki served as a non-affiliated independent member of the cabinet during both the [[Civic Platform]] and [[Polish People's Party]] coalition governments under Tusk and later Prime Minister [[Ewa Kopacz]].{{cite news|title=Poland's new government wins support|url=http://www.europeanvoice.com/article/2011/november/poland-s-new-government-wins-support/72688.aspx|accessdate=28 March 2013|work=European Voice|date=19 November 2011}} ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} {{s-start}} {{s-gov}} {{s-bef|before=[[Jerzy Miller (politician)|Jerzy Miller]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Ministry of Interior (Poland)|Interior Minister of Poland]]|years=2011 – 2013}} {{s-aft|after=[[Bartłomiej Sienkiewicz]]}} {{s-end}} {{Second Donald Tusk Cabinet}} {{Ewa Kopacz Cabinet}} {{Ministers of the Interior of Poland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cichocki, Jacek}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Politicians from Warsaw]] [[Category:University of Warsaw alumni]] [[Category:Interior ministers of Poland]] [[Category:Leaders of organizations]]

{{+r|date=October 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Jamie Grace | image = Jamie Grace 2014.jpg | caption = Grace performing at the Road Show at the [[Honda Center]] in 2014 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Jamie Grace Harper{{cite web|title=Jamie Grace Harper Born 11/25/1991 in California |publisher=California Birth Index |author=California Birth Index |url=http://www.californiabirthindex.org/birth/jamie_grace_harper_born_1991_20677039 |accessdate=April 7, 2015}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1991|11|25}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]] | origin = [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]] | instrument = Vocals, guitar | genre = [[Contemporary Christian music|Contemporary Christian]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Christian hip hop]] | occupation = [[Singer]], [[rapping|rapper]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 2009–present | label = [[Gotee Records|Gotee]] | associated_acts = | url = {{URL|jamiegrace.com}} }} '''Jamie Grace Harper''' (born November 25, 1991){{cite web|title=Jamie Grace Discography, Jamie Grace Artist Database, Jamie Grace-Harper |url=http://www.jesusfreakhideout.com/artists/JamieGrace.asp|publisher=jesusfreakhideout.com |accessdate=June 2, 2011}} is an American [[contemporary Christian music]]ian, singer, rapper, and songwriter from [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. In 2010, [[TobyMac]] found her songs on [[YouTube]] and signed her to his label [[Gotee Records]] for two albums. She released the song "Hold Me" in 2011 which landed her a nomination at the [[54th Grammy Awards|2012 Grammys]] and won the 2012 [[Dove Award for New Artist of the Year]]. == Background == Grace was born Jamie Grace Harper and is the youngest daughter to James and Mona Harper.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} She grew up singing and playing instruments in both church and at home with her older sister Morgan.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} She was home-schooled with her sister, [[Morgan Harper Nichols]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/news/local/teens-creativity-starts-at-home/nQZst |title=Teens' creativity starts at home |publisher=ajc.com |date=December 10, 2009 |accessdate=October 24, 2013}} On July 16, 2006, she created a [[YouTube]] account and began posting videos of her songs online.{{cite web|url=http://jamiegrace.com/about |title=Info |publisher=Jamiegrace.com |accessdate=September 4, 2013}} Over the years her videos received recognition from [[Audio Adrenaline]]'s [[Mark Stuart (musician)|Mark Stuart]], [[David Mullen (singer)|David Mullen]] and eventually landing her a singing and acting gig with the television show ''[[iShine]]'', and subsequent tour. In 2010 she was discovered by [[TobyMac]] and signed to his record label [[Gotee Records]] later that year. {{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} Grace's debut [[Extended play|EP]], ''[[Hold Me (Jamie Grace EP)|Hold Me]]'', was released by the label on February 22, 2011.[http://www.jesusfreakhideout.com/cdreviews/HoldMeEP.asp Jesusfreakhideout.com: Jamie Grace, "Hold Me EP" Review] jesusfreakhideout.com. Retrieved March 23, 2011. Jamie Grace released the title track to the album at the same time and it was one of the most added singles to Christian Hit Radio stations.{{cite web|title=Jamie Grace's Hold Me e.p. Releases Digitally, February 22 |url=http://www.cmspin.com/newsmanager/anmviewer.asp?a=6245&z=1 |publisher=CM Spin |accessdate=April 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110307135227/http://www.cmspin.com/newsmanager/anmviewer.asp?a=6245&z=1 |archivedate=March 7, 2011 |df= }} Her debut album, ''[[One Song at a Time]]'', was released in stores September 20, 2011. Her second EP, ''Christmas Together'', was released November 29, 2011.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} Grace was featured as a main artist and speaker in the Revolve Tour by [[Women of Faith]][http://revolvetour.com/artists-speakers/jamie-grace-harper Jamie-Grace Harper << The Revolve Tour] revolvetour.com. Retrieved March 23, 2011. alongside artists such as [[Britt Nicole]], [[Group 1 Crew]], and [[Hawk Nelson]].[http://www.ktis.fm/lastday.php?day=0 Recently Played – 98.5 KTIS] ktis.fm. Retrieved March 5, 2011 On May 4, 2011, Jesus Freak Hideout announced that "Hold Me," her first single, had attained the No. 1 spot at CHR.[http://www.jesusfreakhideout.com/news/2011/05/04.Jamie%20Graces%20Debut%20Single%20Hold%20Me%20Hits%20No.%201.asp Jesusfreakhideout.com Music News, May 2011: Jamie Grace's Debut Single "Hold Me" Hits No. 1] jesusfreakhideout.com. Retrieved May 5, 2011. Her second studio album, ''[[Ready to Fly (Jamie Grace album)|Ready to Fly]]'', produced by [[Christopher Stevens (musician)|Christopher Stevens]] and David Garcia, was released January 28, 2014. The first single was "Beautiful Day".{{cite web|url=http://www.breathecast.com/articles/jamie-grace-ready-to-fly-sophomore-album-12193/ |title=Jamie Grace Reveals Upcoming Album 'Ready To Fly', Release Date, Features and More : BC News |publisher=breathecast |accessdate=February 19, 2014}} The second single available was "Fighter", an inspiring song about those who have struggled but don't give up.[http://theundergroundsite.com/album-review-ready-to-fly-by-jamie-grace/ "Album review: ‘Ready To Fly’ by Jamie Grace"]. ''The Underground. ''Retrieved February 18, 2014. She was a part of the Winter Jam Tour 2015 West Coast.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} In August 2016, Jamie Grace and her sister, fellow artist Morgan Harper Nichols, announced her departure from Gotee Records.{{cite web|url=http://www.artsoulradio.com/jamie-grace-no-longer-with-gotee-records-announces-new-music/|title=Jamie Grace No Longer with Gotee Records - Announces New Music!|accessdate=September 5, 2016}} On November 25, 2016, Jamie Grace released "Party Like a Princess" to most major music streaming services, which was released as a promotional single for both her 25th birthday and her upcoming third studio album.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} In February 2017, Grace announced that the album would be delayed to allow Grace to address issues around her mother's health.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/jamiegraceh/status/834951393521774592 |work=Twitter Post |author=Jamie Grace|publisher=Twitter |accessdate=February 24, 2017}} On April 21, Grace released the lead single, ''The Happy Song'', from the new album.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nabrmNTrBiU |title=Jamie Grace - The Happy Song |via=YouTube|author=Jamie Grace|accessdate=July 25, 2017}} On July 11, Grace, streaming live on [[YouTube]], announced that the album would be titled '''91'', and would be released on September 1, 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nabrmNTrBiU |title=Pre-Order '91: MY NEW ALBUM!! - available 9.1.17 |publisher=Jamie Grace|author=Jamie Grace |accessdate=July 25, 2017}} Ten days later, on July 21, Grace posted the second single, ''Daughter of a King'', on YouTube{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4-spC-Ps3Uw |title=Jamie Grace - Jamie Grace - Daughter of The King ft. Morgan Harper Nichols |via=YouTube|author=Jamie Grace|accessdate=July 25, 2017}} On September 1, 2017, the fourteen-track album was released. Shortly thereafter, she introduced a new project, '''91 Anthems''; a YouTube endeavor featuring 91 original songs and covers recorded inspired by stories submitted by fans.{{Cite web|url=https://www.91anthems.com/|title=Miller|website='91 Anthems - by Jamie Grace|language=en-US|access-date=September 26, 2018}} Since then, she has released another single, "Wait it Out", and is working on new music as well. == Musical style == In a somewhat unusual style, Jamie Grace combines elements of [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], [[Folk music|folk]], and [[Pop music|pop]] into one distinct sound."[http://theundergroundsite.com/ready-to-fly-5-questions-with-jamie-grace/ Ready to Fly: 5 Questions with Jamie Grace]". Retrieved February 18, 2014. She occasionally uses elements of guest vocalists, such as [[TobyMac]] in "Hold Me" and GabeReal from [[The Diverse City Band|DiverseCity]] in "One Song at a Time" on ''[[Hold Me (EP)|Hold Me]]''. == Personal life == Grace graduated from [[Point University]] with a bachelor's degree in children's ministry.{{cite web |last= Moring |first=Mark|date= November 21, 2012| title= Jamie Grace is holding on |work= Christianity Today |url= http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2012/november/holding-on.html|accessdate=August 1, 2016}} She has [[Tourette syndrome]] and [[obsessive–compulsive disorder]]. In 2016, she was called up onto the stage at an [[Adele]] concert. She then sang a cover of "I Can't Help Falling in Love With You" – originally sung by Elvis – and Adele said that she had a great voice.{{cite web |last= Sarachik |first= Justin |date= August 10, 2016 | title= Adele is Wowed by Jamie-Grace's Powerful Cover at Concert |work= Rapzilla |url= http://www.rapzilla.com/rz/features/13905-adele-is-wowed-by-jamie-grace-s-powerful-cover-at-concert}} On January 25, 2018, Grace announced that she had become engaged to Aaron Collins.{{cite web |last= Grace |first=Jamie |date= January 25, 2018| title= I Said Yes |work= Instagram |url= https://www.instagram.com/p/BeZQUlEBC_0/|accessdate=February 16, 2018}} The couple were married on April 14, 2018.{{cite web|last1=Spain|first1=Jamie|title=Christian Singer with Tourette Syndrome, Jamie Grace, Marries Fiancé After 5-Month Courtship|url=http://people.com/music/christian-singer-with-tourette-syndrome-jamie-grace-marries-fiance-a-after-5-month-courtship/|website=People Music|publisher=Jamie Spain|accessdate=May 5, 2018|ref=21}} == Discography == === Albums === {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Details ! colspan="2"| Peak chart

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:De Vigne Julius 070513.gif|thumb|200px|right|Julius de Vigne]] --> '''Julius De Vigne''' ([[Ghent]], 19 November 1844 – 1906) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] lawyer, politician and writer. He studied law at the [[University of Ghent]] and established himself as a lawyer. For several years, he was a member of the provincial - and municipal Council of Ghent. As a student at the university, he contributed to the student almanacs, published by the [[Flanders|Flemish]] literary student organization [['t zal wel gaan]]. When the Flemish weekly ''Het Volksbelang'' was founded by [[Julius Vuylsteke]], in 1867, he was one of the editors together with [[Julius Sabbe]], [[Jozef Van Hoorde]], and [[Adolf Hoste]].
In 1883 he was the primary supporter of the third ''Taalwet'' (E: language law), which stated that at the public schools and ''Royal Athenaea'' in [[Flanders]], education would be preferably in [[Dutch language|Dutch]] instead of [[French language|French]].
==Bibliography== * Kiezers-handboek of uitleggingen op de Belgische kieswetten, Gent 1871 * Belgische kieswetboek van 18 Mei 1872, Nederlandsche vertaling met ophelderingen, Gent 1872 * De Zuidnederlandsche schrijvers van het tijdstip der Fransche Overheersching, Antw. 1873 * De wet op de jacht van 29 Maart 1873 * Reglement op de insectenvretende vogels, met Nederlandsche vertaling, Gent 1874 * De Staatswetten van België, (Grondwet, Provinciale wet, Gemeentewet, Kieswetboek), officiëele tekst met Nederlandsche vertaling, Gent 1874 * De Diensttijd in het Leger, Gent 1887.
==See also== * [[Flemish literature]]
==Sources== * [http://www.dbnl.nl/tekst/wink002ontw07_01/wink002ontw07_01_0019.htm De Vlaamsche beweging en de Vlaamsche Poëzie] * [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/bran038biog01_01/bran038biog01_01_4291.htm Julius De Vigne]
